conclusion: Determine when the two objects meet by examining the velocity-time graph.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the object.
Objects meet when the areas under the curves for both objects are equal.
For Object A, the area under the curve is represented by the shaded regions.
For Object B, the area under the curve is also represented by the shaded regions.
At \( t_1 \), Object A has moved some distance, but Object B has not started moving yet.
At \( t_2 \), Object A continues to accumulate distance, but Object B starts gaining velocity.
At \( t_3 \), the shaded areas under both curves are equal, suggesting the displacements are the same.
Beyond \( t_3 \), Object B continues to increase its area under the curve, surpassing Object A.
The objects meet when the shaded areas under both curves are equal, occurring at \( t_3 \).
